paragraphs.text: %md ## OML4R Feature Selection Using Summary Statistics In this notebook, we demonstrate how to perform feature selection using summary statistics via OML4R. Using the customer insurance lifetime value data set, which contains customer financial information, lifetime value, and whether or not the customer bought insurance, we show how to use OML4R to select features based on number of distinct values, null values, proportion of constant values. The dataset `CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV_R` is generated by the `"OML Run-me-first"` notebook, which `MUST` be run before this notebook. --- ##### `IMPORTANT`: The `"OML Run-me-first"` notebook is available under the menu Templates -> Examples and is a pre-requisite to the current notebook. --- Copyright (c) 2022 Oracle Corporation ###### The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0 ---

msg.data:
OML4R Feature Selection Using Summary Statistics

In this notebook, we demonstrate how to perform feature selection using summary statistics via OML4R.

Using the customer insurance lifetime value data set, which contains customer financial information, lifetime value, and whether or not the customer bought insurance, we show how to use OML4R to select features based on number of distinct values, null values, proportion of constant values.

The dataset CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV_R is generated by the "OML Run-me-first" notebook, which MUST be run before this notebook.

IMPORTANT: The "OML Run-me-first" notebook is available under the menu Templates -> Examples and is a pre-requisite to the current notebook.

Copyright (c) 2022 Oracle Corporation

The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

paragraphs.text: %md OML4R documentation on Data Preparation: https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/machine-learning/oml4r/1.5.1/oreug/preparing-data-in-database-using-ORE.html

msg.data: OML4R documentation on Data Preparation: https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/machine-learning/oml4r/1.5.1/oreug/preparing-data-in-database-using-ORE.html

Attaching package: ‘OREdplyr’


The following objects are masked from ‘package:dplyr’:

    arrange, arrange_, count, count_, cume_dist, dense_rank, desc,
    distinct, distinct_, filter, filter_, first, full_join, group_by,
    group_by_, group_size, groups, inner_join, last, left_join,
    min_rank, mutate, mutate_, n, n_distinct, n_groups, nth, ntile,
    percent_rank, rename, rename_, right_join, row_number, sample_frac,
    sample_n, select, select_, slice, slice_, summarise, summarise_,
    tally, top_n, transmute, transmute_, ungroup


The following object is masked from ‘package:stats’:

    filter

paragraphs.title: Get proxy object for CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV table
paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.sync(table = 'CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV_R', use.keys= FALSE)
ore.attach()


CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV <- CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV_R

row.names(CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV) <- CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV$CUSTOMER_ID

numRows <- nrow(CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV)

paragraphs.title: Check the unique values in each column
paragraphs.text:
%r

unique_counts <- mapply(OREdplyr::n_distinct,CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV)

unique_counts_df <- as.data.frame(unique_counts)
unique_counts_df$rownames <- rownames(unique_counts_df)
colnames(unique_counts_df) <- c('CNT', 'FEATURE')
z.show(unique_counts_df)

paragraphs.title: Filter categorical 'identifier' columns - filter out columns with > 95% unique values
paragraphs.text:
%r

ratio <- 0.95
threshold <- numRows*ratio
unique_cat_cols <- unique_counts[cat_cols]
selected_cat_cols <- names(unique_cat_cols)[unique_cat_cols < threshold & unique_cat_cols > 1]
selected_cat_cols
length(selected_cat_cols)

paragraphs.title: For all columns, identify columns with > 40% missing values
paragraphs.text:
%r

ratio <- 0.4
threshold <- numRows*ratio
count_na <- as.list(colSums(is.na(CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV)))
count_na <- Filter(function(x) any(x>threshold), count_na)
many_missing_cols <- names(count_na)
many_missing_cols

paragraphs.title: Filter 'constant' columns - those with > 90% same values
paragraphs.text:
%r

ratio <- 0.90
threshold <- numRows*ratio
tables <- mapply(table,CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV)
tables <- Filter(function(x) any(x>threshold), tables)
major_constant_cols <- names(tables)
major_constant_cols

paragraphs.title: Create an OML dataframe with 'constant' columns and missing value columns filtered out

paragraphs.title: Build a Naive Bayes Classification model to predict who will purchase insurance using the selected attributes

msg.data:
Call:
ore.odmNB(formula = BUY_INSURANCE ~ ., data = SELECTED_DF)

Settings: 
                                               value
clas.weights.balanced                            OFF
odms.details                             odms.enable
odms.missing.value.treatment odms.missing.value.auto
odms.sampling                  odms.sampling.disable
prep.auto                                         ON

name: OML4R Feature Selection Using Summary Statistics
